The text describes a program at George Brown College focused on harnessing local economies and cultures of food and drink for successful and resilient tourism experiences. Graduates may find career opportunities in various roles related to culinary tourism, such as tourism entrepreneur, culinary tourism program manager, communications coordinator, travel consultant, food and beverage manager, and conference services manager. These opportunities exist at local and international tourism attractions, culinary travel agencies/tour groups/associations, restaurants and resorts, farms and fisheries providing tourism experiences, wineries, breweries, cideries and distillers, destination marketing and development organizations, and government agencies. The program includes six courses per semester during the first two semesters, followed by independent research projects and a work-integrated learning experience in the third semester. Potential career options include those mentioned above. The food tourism sector is experiencing growth and innovation, with Canadians spending $43 billion a year outside the country and inbound visitors to Canada spending $22 billion. There is an opportunity within Canada to capture 25% of outbound revenue as noted by Marsha Walden, President and CEO of Destination Canada.

The graduate certificate program is offered in the field of Food Tourism and is suitable for graduates from various backgrounds including Baking and Pastry Arts Management (H113), Culinary Management (H100/H116), Culinary Management – Nutrition (H119), Food and Beverage Management – Restaurant Management (H132), Hotel Operations Management (H133), Event Planning (H141), Tourism and Hospitality Management (H130), and a wide range of business programs.

The program consists of three semesters, with Semester 1 courses being HOST 1165 - Gastronomy and Tastes of Place 1, HOST 1166 - Entrepreneurship in Food Tourism, HOST 1167 - Leadership and Innovation in Food Tourism, HOST 1168 - Food Tourism Marketing, HOST 1169 - Circular Economy and Sustainable Chef, and HOST 1170 - Global Tourism Management.

Semester 2 courses are HOST 1211 - Gastronomy and Tastes of Place 2, HOST 1212 - Event Planning in Food Tourism, HOST 1213 - Fundamentals of Wine and Beverage for Food Tourism, HOST 1214 - Food Writing and Social Media of Food, HOST 1215 - Sustainable Tourism and Ecopreneurship, and HOST 1216 - Research Methods in Food Tourism.

Semester 3 courses include HOST 1303 - Special Topics in Food Tourism Entrepreneurship and HOST 1304 - Externship/Field Placement.

The program learning outcomes include researching and assessing local, national, and global environments for food and beverage tourism opportunities that connect to local producers and provide tourists with authentic destination experiences; developing sustainable food and beverage tourism products and experiences that equitably support the local environment and economy while recognizing diverse cultural needs, experiences, and practices of local and global communities; designing marketing strategies to promote existing and new food enterprises, products, and experiences using various platforms appropriate to the target market; and developing business plans for sustainable food enterprises.

* Applicants with international transcripts who do not provide English proficiency test results must take the George Brown College English assessment.
* Applicants accepted based on work experience only will also be required to take the English Admissions Assessment.
* International students can visit the English Proficiency page for more details about English language proficiency requirements.
* International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
* For inquiries about financial aid, contact the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid web page.
* For School of Hospitality and Tourism Management–related inquiries, contact chcastudentsupport@georgebrown.ca.
* Contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions web page for inquiries about domestic admission requirements, admission deadlines, or the admissions process.
* For more information about George Brown College, contact the Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.
* International students can contact one of George Brown College's international recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry on the International Contact Us page.
* Visit the campus for an upcoming Discovery Day to learn more about areas of interest.
* Students should be aware that various allergens, including nuts, dairy and shellfish, are routinely used in practice labs. George Brown College is sensitive to religious observances but may not meet specific dietary laws related to halal and kosher foods.
* Applicants with queries regarding Health Policy should contact the college for further details.
